Chief Complaint: 69 yom  with h/o CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin, DM-II
   presenting to ED with acute onset of flank pain.  Workup in the ED
   revealed right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular
   hemorrhage.  Since admission to the floor, he has received a total of 3
   units PRBC's and 6 units FFP in attempt to support patient and reverse
   INR.  Patients urine output has continued to fall and he remains
   minimally responsive to high dose Lasix bolluses.  Patient also began
   to experience asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular
   tachycardia with alternating axis
   24 Hour Events:
   - CT abd/pelvis: no significant change from prior study, areas of
   subcapsular and intraparenchymal hemorrhage without sig. increase in RP
   hematoma, small right pleural effusion, increased opacity at left lung
   base c/w atelectasis vs. aspiration
   - renal recs: urine sediment c/w ATN, dose meds for GFR = 0, agree w/
   diuretic trial
   - urology recs: reverse INR, f/u CT on Monday, follow serial HCT, will
   require MR in 3 months for further evaluation
   - bladder pressure inc. to 21 (stable), general surgery contact[**Name (NI) **] which
   reports no intervention unless > 30
   - HCT  trends down: 38.6 -> 29.5 -> 27.0 -> 25.3 -> 20.2 (1 unit) ->
   21.0 (2 units)-> 26.2 = 3 units total
   - INR trends down: 2.5 -> 2.3 -> 2.4 -> 2.2 -> 1.8 = 6 units FFP
   - Lasix boluses 80mg then 120 mg with UOP around 30 cc/hr
   - episode of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with shifting axis,
   electrolytes normal, patient asymptomatic and exam unremarkable, VSS,
   cardiac enzymes cycled and 1st set normal
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Pantoprazole (Protonix) - [**2190-10-31**] 08:05 PM
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2190-10-31**] 10:32 PM
   Hydromorphone (Dilaudid) - [**2190-11-1**] 03:10 AM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:

                             [**2190-10-31**]  04:47 AM
                             [**2190-10-31**]  12:28 PM
                             [**2190-10-31**]  06:09 PM
                             [**2190-11-1**]  01:55 AM
   WBC

   Glucose
   265
   255
   244
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:20.1/28.6/1.9, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:228/7/0.06, Ca++:7.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:5.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   .
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.
   -- will call urology this am to touch base about the decreased urine
   output
   -- will give another 2 units FFP given possible progression of bleed
   -- cont holding warfarin, aspirin
   -- would lke to give RBC transfusion, but will hold given volume
   .
   (#) ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: unclear what his baseline is (seems
   to be in mid 2's); acute change with minimal UOP in last few hours is
   concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to
   the kidney or IVC; also has a mildly elevated lactate.
   -- will repeat pelvis CT scan
   -Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY
   -- renal diet when restarted
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE AMI: ST changes on EKG ordered for eval of nausea (not CP,
   albeit pt is diabetic) were considered "artifact" by cards fellow and
   normalized on repeat EKG.
   -- CE ordered with am labs though low suspicion will be positive
   -- cont statin; hold ASA given bleed
   .
   (#) Fever/Leukocytosis -  WBC currently 13.6 with left shift. Infection
   is highest on differential, although stress reaction to acute bleed,
   inflammatory, and neoplastic disease are also possible. No evidence fo
   PNA currently (though may have had an aspirtaion event last night).
   -- continue to monitor
   -- Check urine culture, blood culture
   .
   # CHF (h/o systolic dysfunction, though normalized on [**2188**] echo): Pt
   reports history of mild edema and recent weight gain. Known systolic
   dysfunction although LVEF in [**2188**] >55%.
   -Strict I's and O's
   -monitor respiratory status, vital signs
   -- might consider repeat echo
   .
   #Atrial fibrillation: Hx of inducible VT, s/p upgrade to a BiV ICD [**2186**]
   (defibrillated 1x).
   -holding coumadin
   -continue telemetry
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].
   -HISS
   - [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 1936**] of [**Last Name (un) 303**] folows his DM, as pt is on a study drug for
   kidney disease
   .
   #HTN: Currently stable though on low side with possible IVC compression
   from hematoma.  Will be cautious with antihypertensives in setting of
   bleed.
   - furosemide according to BP parameters
   -hold metoprolol and valsartan, reasses if needed
   .
   #Hypothyroidism: Stable, continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   .
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code: presumed full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 10486**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10487**]
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2190-10-31**] 08:11 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. **Retroperitoneal hemorrhage (RP) progression**: The patient's urine output has decreased, and creatinine levels have increased, indicating potential progression of the RP hemorrhage, which can lead to further compromise of renal perfusion and potentially life-threatening consequences.
2. **Acute on chronic renal failure**: The patient's acute change in renal function, combined with minimal urine output, is concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to the kidney or IVC. This can lead to further deterioration of renal function and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. **Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB)**: The patient's episode of guaiac-positive emesis, nausea, and vomiting raise concerns for UGIB, which can lead to hemorrhagic shock and potentially life-threatening consequences.
4. **Aspiration**: The patient's emesis and possible aspiration event may lead to respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, which can worsen his overall condition.
5. **Cardiac complications**: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation, inducible VT, and recent ICD upgrade make him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, which can lead to cardiac arrest or life-threatening complications.
6. **Infection**: The patient's leukocytosis and left shift may indicate an underlying infection, which can spread to other parts of the body and lead to life-threatening complications.
7. **Fluid overload**: The patient's fluid balance is concerning, with a total input of 2,084 mL and a total output of 342 mL, indicating potential fluid overload, which can lead to respiratory and cardiovascular complications.
8. **Electrolyte imbalance**: The patient's electrolyte levels, particularly potassium and magnesium, are concerning, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other life-threatening complications.
9. **Coagulopathy**: The patient's INR has decreased, indicating potential coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding complications and potentially life-threatening consequences.
10. **Nutritional deficiencies**: The patient's NPO status and potential malnutrition may lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients, which can worsen his overall condition and increase the risk of complications.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's condition to prevent further deterioration and potential life-threatening consequences.

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - hold on repeat CT scan this AM as patient does not appear stable for
   study
   - consult with urology re: need for CT and how it would change
   management
   - q 6  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   - continue to trend bladder pressures for concern of abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - f/u KUB for evaluate of ileus
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - attempt Lasix 120  mg IV bolus in hopes of mobilizing fluid off lungs
   - close renal contact re: management of ARF and consideration of HD
   - renally dose all medications
   ## Hypoxia:  patient initially presented with desaturations in the ED
   with concern for volume overload as evidenced by CXR.  Patient had TTE
   performed to evaluate for cardiac function which was limited but which
   did not suggest decompensated heart failure.  Of note, patient also has
   history of obstructive lung disease and requires BiPAP at night for
   OSA.  Patient now saturating in low-mid 90
s on 4L NC.
   - continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
   - attempt diuresis as discussed above
   - continue scheduled nebulizer treatments
   - prepare for endotracheal intubation of respiratory status becomes
   worse
   - consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration PNA given episode of
   emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening CXR
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - attempt rate control with metoprolol / diltiazem
   - consult EP for pacer interrogation
   - continue to holding ASA in setting of RP bleed
   - restart home dose Metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 7**]
   ## Fever / Leukocytosis:  WBC continues to remain elevated without
   obvious infectious source.  This may represent demargination from
   generalized inflammatory response given RP bleed.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures and CXR
   ## Concern for UGIB:  patient had single reported episode of guiac
   positive post-tussive emesis in setting of severe cough.  Of note,
   patient has no risk factors variceal bleed and no history suggestive of
   UGIB.  Suspicion for UGIB is very low.
   - check stool guiac
 if positive will require GI consult
   - continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**] for now
   # CHF: unclear to extent of disease with last documented LVEF > 55%.
   TTE performed on day of admission showed mild progression of LVEF
   dysfunction.
   - continue scheduled albuterol and atrovent nebs
   - continue to attempt diuresis
   - formal echo for better evaluation of cardiac function
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Sugars have been poorly controlled in the mid-upper 200
   - increase AM Lantus to 44 units for improved basal coverage with HISS
   for breakthrough
   - contact [**Name (NI) 631**] re: DM management
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   # Access: attain better access with 16 gauge peripheral IV
s vs.
   Midline

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels have risen to 5.8 mg/dL, indicating a possible AKI. The patient's urine output has been falling, and the urine sediment shows signs of Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN).
2. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS): The patient's bladder pressure is elevated to 21 mmHg, which may indicate a risk of ACS. The patient's abdominal distension and tense abdomen also suggest a possible ACS.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 92% on 4L NC, indicating a possible respiratory failure. The patient's chest X-ray shows mild bibasilar atelectasis, and the patient has a history of obstructive lung disease.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is a significant concern. The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, and the patient has a history of systolic heart failure.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's guaiac-positive stool suggests a possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's history of aspirin and coumadin use may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and fever suggest a possible infection. The patient's blood and urine cultures are pending, and the patient's chest X-ray shows mild bibasilar atelectasis.
7. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen saturation is 92% on 4L NC, indicating a possible hypoxia. The patient's history of obstructive lung disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) may increase the risk of hypoxia.

In terms of management, the patient requires close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies. The patient's AKI and ATN require close monitoring and management with diuretics and hemodialysis if necessary. The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome requires close monitoring of his bladder pressure and abdominal distension. The patient's respiratory failure requires close monitoring of his oxygen saturation and respiratory status. The patient's cardiac complications require close monitoring of his cardiac enzymes and cardiac function. The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding requires close monitoring of his stool guaiac and abdominal imaging studies. The patient's infection requires close monitoring of his blood and urine cultures and chest X-ray.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage.

The patient has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse his international normalized ratio (INR). Despite this, his urine output has continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose furosemide (Lasix) boluses.

The patient has developed asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis, and his cardiac enzymes are normal. His troponin-T levels are elevated, but his creatine kinase (CK) and CK-MB levels are normal.

The patient's laboratory results show a rising creatinine level (5.8 mg/dL) and a low hematocrit (20.2%). His white blood cell count is elevated, and his platelet count is low.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and acute kidney injury (AKI) due to the poor perfusion and hypoxia. He has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR).

The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he requires oxygen therapy to maintain a saturation of 92%. His abdominal compartment syndrome is a concern, and his bladder pressure is increasing.

The patient's medications include pantoprazole, furosemide, and hydromorphone. He has also been prescribed antibiotics, and his blood cultures are pending.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including:

1. Retroperitoneal bleed: The patient has a bleeding disorder, and his INR is elevated. He requires continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further bleeding.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient has developed ATN and AKI due to the poor perfusion and hypoxia. He requires continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further kidney damage.
3. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient has developed AFib with RVR, which is a life-threatening condition. He requires continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.
4. Hypoxia: The patient has developed hypoxia due to the respiratory failure. He requires continued oxygen therapy and monitoring to prevent further complications.
5. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient has developed abdominal compartment syndrome, which is a life-threatening condition. He requires continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.

Based on the patient's condition, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Further bleeding: The patient's bleeding disorder and elevated INR make him at risk for further bleeding.
2. Kidney damage: The patient's ATN and AKI can lead to further kidney damage if not treated promptly.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's AFib with RVR can lead to cardiac complications, such as heart failure, if not treated promptly.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure can lead to further complications, such as respiratory arrest, if not treated promptly.
5. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome can lead to further complications, such as organ failure, if not treated promptly.

The patient requires continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications and to improve his condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) on coumadin, who presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of flank pain. The patient was found to have a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage, which was managed with 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support hemodynamics and reverse the international normalized ratio (INR).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) mask with an SpO2 of 92%. The chest X-ray (CXR) shows mild bibasilar atelectasis and a tiny right pleural effusion.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and is receiving metoprolol for rate control.
* Renal: The patient has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with rising creatinine (Cr) levels (2.3 to 5.8 mg/dL) and falling urine output (UOP).
* Gastrointestinal: The patient had a single episode of guaiac-positive post-tussive emesis, which may be related to upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB).
* Neurological: The patient is minimally responsive and has not been assessed for peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic function.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of renal function: The patient's Cr levels are rising, and the UOP is falling, which may indicate worsening ATN.
2. Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's CXR shows mild bibasilar atelectasis, and the SpO2 is 92%, which may indicate early signs of ARDS.
3. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient had a single episode of guaiac-positive post-tussive emesis, which may be related to UGIB.
4. Infection: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and is at risk for developing an infection, particularly in the setting of a prolonged hospital stay.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which may increase the risk of cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is receiving levothyroxine sodium, which may need to be adjusted based on the patient's current condition.
7. Gout: The patient has a history of gout and is receiving allopurinol, which may need to be adjusted based on the patient's current condition.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions, including acute kidney injury, atrial fibrillation, and upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - repeat CT scan this AM to evaluate for interval change
   - q 8  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   ## Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - hold Lasix bolus for now considering rising Cr
   - f/u renal re: management of progressive ARF w/ poor UOP in the
   setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
   - renally dose all medications
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.
   -- will call urology this am to touch base about the decreased urine
   output
   -- will give another 2 units FFP given possible progression of bleed
   -- cont holding warfarin, aspirin
   -- would lke to give RBC transfusion, but will hold given volume
   .
   (#) ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: unclear what his baseline is (seems
   to be in mid 2's); acute change with minimal UOP in last few hours is
   concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to
   the kidney or IVC; also has a mildly elevated lactate.
   -- will repeat pelvis CT scan
   -Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY
   -- renal diet when restarted
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE AMI: ST changes on EKG ordered for eval of nausea (not CP,
   albeit pt is diabetic) were considered "artifact" by cards fellow and
   normalized on repeat EKG.
   -- CE ordered with am labs though low suspicion will be positive
   -- cont statin; hold ASA given bleed
   .
   (#) Fever/Leukocytosis -  WBC currently 13.6 with left shift. Infection
   is highest on differential, although stress reaction to acute bleed,
   inflammatory, and neoplastic disease are also possible. No evidence fo
   PNA currently (though may have had an aspirtaion event last night).
   -- continue to monitor
   -- Check urine culture, blood culture
   .
   # CHF (h/o systolic dysfunction, though normalized on [**2188**] echo): Pt
   reports history of mild edema and recent weight gain. Known systolic
   dysfunction although LVEF in [**2188**] >55%.
   -Strict I's and O's
   -monitor respiratory status, vital signs
   -- might consider repeat echo
   .
   #Atrial fibrillation: Hx of inducible VT, s/p upgrade to a BiV ICD [**2186**]
   (defibrillated 1x).
   -holding coumadin
   -continue telemetry
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].
   -HISS
   - [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 1936**] of [**Last Name (un) 303**] folows his DM, as pt is on a study drug for
   kidney disease
   .
   #HTN: Currently stable though on low side with possible IVC compression
   from hematoma.  Will be cautious with antihypertensives in setting of
   bleed.
   - furosemide according to BP parameters
   -hold metoprolol and valsartan, reasses if needed
   .
   #Hypothyroidism: Stable, continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   .
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   .

   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .

   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - repeat CT scan this AM to evaluate for interval change
   - q 8  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   ## Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - hold Lasix bolus for now considering rising Cr
   - f/u renal re: management of progressive ARF w/ poor UOP in the
   setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
   - renally dose all medications
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context

   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since

   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.

Based on the provided medical progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and diabetes mellitus type II. He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. He has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma in an attempt to support his hemodynamics and reverse his elevated international normalized ratio (INR).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability with a blood pressure of 98/53 mmHg and a heart rate of 99 beats per minute.
* Respiratory compromise with a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 19 mmHg and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 30 mmHg.
* Renal failure with a creatinine level of 5.8 mg/dL and a urine output of 30 cc/hr.
* Electrolyte imbalance with a potassium level of 4.5 mmol/L and a magnesium level of 2.0 mmol/L.
* Hypoxia with an oxygen saturation of 92%.
* Abnormal electrocardiogram (ECG) findings, including wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis.
* Elevated troponin-T level, suggesting possible myocardial infarction (MI).
* Possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) with guaiac-positive emesis.
* Fever and leukocytosis, suggesting possible infection.

The patient is currently receiving the following treatments:

* Inotropic support with dopamine and dobutamine.
* Vasopressor support with norepinephrine.
* Fluid resuscitation with crystalloid and colloid solutions.
* Blood transfusions with packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma.
* Anticoagulation therapy with heparin and warfarin.
* Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel.
* Antibiotic therapy with cefepime and aztreonam.
* Antiemetic therapy with ondansetron and metoclopramide.
* Pain management with morphine and fentanyl.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further hemorrhage and bleeding complications.
* Renal failure and acute kidney injury (AKI).
* Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Cardiac complications, including MI, cardiac tamponade, and cardiac arrest.
* Infection and sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
* Hypoxia and hypoperfusion.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following recommendations are made:

* Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust treatment accordingly.
* Continue to provide respiratory support and consider intubation if necessary.
* Continue to provide renal support and consider dialysis if necessary.
* Continue to provide antibiotic therapy and consider adding additional antibiotics if necessary.
* Continue to provide anticoagulation therapy and consider adding additional anticoagulants if necessary.
* Continue to provide pain management and consider adding additional analgesics if necessary.
* Consider performing a diagnostic procedure, such as a CT scan or an angiogram, to further evaluate the patient's condition.

In conclusion, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a complex medical condition, including acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and cardiac complications. He is at risk for further complications, including hemorrhage, infection, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring and aggressive treatment are necessary to prevent these complications and improve the patient's outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) on coumadin, who presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of flank pain. The patient was found to have a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage, and was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management.

The patient's condition has been complicated by several issues:

1. Retroperitoneal bleed: The patient has an intraparenchymal and subcapsular bleed of the right kidney, which appears stable on serial imaging. However, the patient's urine output has been falling, and his creatinine levels have been rising, suggesting acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to poor perfusion and acute renal failure (ARF).
2. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has marginal urine output, and his creatinine levels are rising, indicating worsening renal function. The patient's urine sediment is consistent with ATN.
3. Hypoxia: The patient initially presented with desaturations in the ED, and has required oxygen therapy. His oxygen saturation is currently in the low-mid 90s on 4 liters of nasal cannula oxygen.
4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR): The patient has developed wide complex, irregular tachycardia with a rate of up to 140 beats per minute, which is becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and dyspnea.
5. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has been elevated, and he has a temperature of 38.1°C (100.5°F). The cause of the fever is unclear, but may be related to the patient's inflammatory response to the retroperitoneal bleed.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's bladder pressure has increased to 21 mmHg, which may indicate impending abdominal compartment syndrome. This could lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not managed promptly.
2. Urosepsis: The patient's urine output is low, and he has a rising creatinine level, which may increase his risk of developing urosepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR may lead to cardiac complications, such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure or pneumonia.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection, which could worsen his condition if not managed promptly.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan has been implemented:

1. Repeat CT scan to evaluate for interval change in the retroperitoneal bleed.
2. Continue to trend bladder pressures to monitor for abdominal compartment syndrome.
3. Hold aspirin and coumadin due to the risk of bleeding.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypoxia with oxygen therapy.
5. Consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration pneumonia if the patient's condition worsens.
6. Consult with the patient's primary care physician to manage his diabetes and other medical conditions.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider formal echocardiogram for better evaluation of cardiac function.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and systolic heart failure. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute onset of flank pain, and workup revealed a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage.

The patient has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse his international normalized ratio (INR). However, his urine output has continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose lasix boluses.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.9 g/dL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 25.3%
* Platelet count: 158 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 5.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 244 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: normal
* Troponin-T: 0.06 ng/mL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Computed tomography (CT) abdomen/pelvis: subcapsular and intraparenchymal hemorrhage without significant increase in renal hematoma, small right pleural effusion, and increased opacity at the left lung base consistent with atelectasis or aspiration.
* Renal ultrasound: urine sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN), dose medications for GFR = 0, and agree with diuretic trial.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acute on chronic renal failure (ACRF)
* Hypoxia
* Concern for upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB)
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR)
* Fever/leukocytosis
* Chronic heart failure (CHF)
* Diabetes mellitus type II (DM-II)
* Hypothyroidism
* Gout

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Progressive acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to hypoperfusion and acute kidney injury
* Worsening of chronic heart failure (CHF)
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to potential infection
* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) or aspiration pneumonia
* Electrolyte imbalances due to chronic kidney disease and acute kidney injury
* Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism due to medication changes or underlying thyroid disease
* Gout flares due to medication changes or underlying gout disease

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Repeat CT scan to evaluate for interval change
* Q8 HCT with PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for goal < 1.9
* Hold aspirin and coumadin
* Continue to trend bladder pressures for concern of abdominal compartment syndrome
* Hold lasix bolus for now considering rising creatinine
* F/u renal re: management of progressive ARF with poor urine output in the setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
* Renally dose all medications
* Continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
* Consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration pneumonia given episode of emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening chest X-ray
* Check stool guaiac if positive will require GI consult
* Continue IV PPI for now
* Maintain active T & S
* Cycle cardiac enzymes
* Attempt rate control with metoprolol
* Consult EP for pacer interrogation
* Continue to hold ASA in setting of right pleural bleed

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   (1)  In AM - complained of chest discomfort and shortness of breath;
   EKG was not concerning however troponins began to rise from .06 -> .12
   -> .15 with CK-MB of 6 -> 11 -> 12.  CK-MB fractions were
   non-significant. Touched base with Dr[**Name (NI) 10535**] coverage who felt this
   was likely secondary to renal failure.
   (2) Began to desaturate into the low 90s in the morning, with use of

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Was desaturating on ventilator, w/ PaO2s in the 70s - 80s on 100%
   FiO2.  Unclear what's causing low saturations but likely
   multifactorial.  Abdominal distension may reduce chest wall compliance,
   leading to hypoxemia.  Secondly, he may have underlying pulmonary edema
   given his biventricular heart failure and that he received multiple
   RBCS + FFPs.  He may also have an underlying  infectious process (white
   count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory sputum is
   growing  4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs and
   chains. Finally, the patient is frequently overbreathing the ventilator
   and appears to be in dyssynchrony with the ventilator.
   -Blood gas has improved considerably this AM on higher PEEP, lower
   tidal volumes, and adjustment of ET tube.  Could decrease FiO2 and PEEP
   as tolerated.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  If in next
   two days, no improvement clinically, consider switching to HAP
   coverage.
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Overall is 3 L positive.  Given that he is
   currently getting CVVH, [**Male First Name (un) **]
t need to aggressively diurese.  Can adjust
   rate of CVVH to keep him slightly negative.
   -Increase sedation as necessary to reduce dyssynchrony.
   .
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for INR
   goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   -Not going for CT given unstable respiratory status
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Patient has creatinine of 6.4, in
   past two days has ranged from 5.3 -> 7.2.   Baseline creatinine is <
   3.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting
   of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led
   to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further
   compromised renal function;
   - Renal following: underwent CVVH starting yesterday.
   -Continue to follow creatinines

s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and

   ## Fever / Leukocytosis:  WBC continues to remain elevated and could be

   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Complications:
	* Hypoxia: The patient is desaturating on the ventilator, with PaO2s in the 70s-80s on 100% FiO2. This may be due to multifactorial causes, including abdominal distension, underlying pulmonary edema, and infectious process.
	* Pneumonia: The patient is growing gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci in sputum, which may indicate a pneumonia.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of VAP.
2. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Cardiac Tamponade: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and a pacer/defibrillator, which may increase the risk of cardiac tamponade.
	* Heart Failure: The patient has biventricular heart failure, which may worsen with fluid overload.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine has increased from 5.3 to 7.2, indicating AKI.
	* Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): The patient has a history of CKD, which may worsen with the current kidney injury.
	* Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is elevated, and the patient is receiving CVVH, which may indicate renal failure.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding (UGIB): The patient has had multiple episodes of coffee-ground material suctioned from the OG tube, which may indicate UGIB.
	* Gastrointestinal Obstruction: The patient has a history of ileus or chronic air swallowing, which may worsen with abdominal distension.
5. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis: The patient's WBC is elevated, and the patient is febrile, which may indicate sepsis.
	* Infection: The patient's sputum is growing gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci, which may indicate an infection.
6. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperglycemia: The patient's sugars have been poorly controlled, and the patient is at risk for hyperglycemia.
	* Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient is receiving IV fluids and electrolyte supplements, which may lead to electrolyte imbalance.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and management of the patient's condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Was desaturating on ventilator, w/ PaO2s in the 70s - 80s on 100%
   FiO2.  Unclear what's causing low saturations but likely
   multifactorial.  Abdominal distension may reduce chest wall compliance,
   leading to hypoxemia.  Secondly, he may have underlying pulmonary edema
   given his biventricular heart failure and that he received multiple
   RBCS + FFPs.  He may also have an underlying  infectious process (white
   count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory sputum is
   growing  4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs and
   chains. Finally, the patient is frequently overbreathing the ventilator
   and appears to be in dyssynchrony with the ventilator.
   -Blood gas has improved considerably this AM on higher PEEP, lower
   tidal volumes, and adjustment of ET tube.  Could decrease FiO2 and PEEP
   as tolerated.
   -Respiratory sputum growing gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  If in next
   two days, no improvement clinically, consider switching to HAP
   coverage.
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Overall is 3 L positive.  Given that he is
   currently getting CVVH, can adjust rate of CVVH to remove -0.5
 1 L of
   fluid daily.
   -Increase sedation as necessary to reduce dyssynchrony.
   .
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - q 6  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   -Not going for CT given unstable respiratory status
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Patient has creatinine of 6.4, in
   past two days has ranged from 5.3 -> 7.2.   Baseline creatinine is <
   3.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting
   of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led
   to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further
   compromised renal function;
   - Renal following: underwent CVVH starting yesterday.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   ## Fever / Leukocytosis:  WBC continues to remain elevated and could be
   secondary to a pneumonia as the patient is growing gram
 rods and gram
   + cocci in sputum.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone
   - f/u blood and urine cultures and CXR
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation, and systolic heart failure. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and possible acute myocardial infarction (AMI). He has been treated with multiple blood products, including packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and fresh frozen plasma (FFP), and is currently receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen saturation has been low, and he has required increasing amounts of oxygen to maintain adequate saturation. The cause of this hypoxia is unclear, but may be related to abdominal distension, pulmonary edema, or an underlying infectious process.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has been rising, and he has been treated with CVVH. The cause of this acute renal failure is unclear, but may be related to the patient's underlying chronic kidney disease, the rupture of a renal cyst, or the use of multiple blood products.
3. Retroperitoneal bleed: The patient has a bleeding disorder, and has received multiple blood products. He has a high international normalized ratio (INR), which may be contributing to his bleeding.
4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR): The patient has an irregular wide complex tachycardia, which is being treated with metoprolol.
5. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient has a fever and elevated white blood cell count, which may be related to a pneumonia or another underlying infection.
6. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB): The patient has been experiencing coffee-ground material suctioned from his nasogastric tube, which may be related to an active UGIB or an old prior bleed.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiac failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's bleeding disorder and high INR may lead to further bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may be related to a pneumonia or another underlying infection, which may worsen if left untreated.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Close monitoring of his oxygen saturation and respiratory status.
2. Treatment of his atrial fibrillation with metoprolol.
3. Continued CVVH to manage his acute renal failure.
4. Treatment of his bleeding disorder with factor replacement therapy.
5. Antibiotics for suspected pneumonia or other underlying infections.
6. Close monitoring of his creatinine and other laboratory values to assess for worsening renal failure.
7. Consideration of insulin therapy to improve glycemic control.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying  nfectious process
   (white count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory
   sputum is growing  4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in
   pairs and chains.  Also abdominal distension may reduce chest wall
   compliance, leading to hypoxemia.  Thirdly, he may have underlying
   pulmonary edema given his biventricular heart failure and that he
   received multiple RBCS + FFPs.  He may also have an  Finally, the
   patient is frequently overbreathing the ventilator and was previously
   in dyssynchrony with ventilator although seems to have improved.
   -Blood gas considerably improved this AM on higher PEEP, lower tidal
   volumes.  Currently on 40% FiO2; could decrease PEEP as tolerated.
   Improvement in CXR also suggests that respiratory status improvement
   likely secondary to continued resolution of PNA.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  White count
   still trending up and re-spiked; if by tomorrow WBC has not improved
   and has continued fevers, expand coverage to HAP.
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Due to CVVH was -2 L overnight, overall is
   now only 1 L positive.  Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to take off
   maximum 1 L today so to keep him at balance.  No need to aggressively
   diurese.
   .
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   - No need for CT for further evaluation given that HCTs have stabilized
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine has been improving 5.6 ->
   4.9 -> 4.4.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in
   setting of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may
   have led to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have
   further compromised renal function;
   - Renal following: underwent CVVH starting yesterday.   Probably may
   have reached new baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -In addition to PR bisacodyl would add soap suds enema
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone; adding vancomycin for coverage
   of enterococcal UTI
   -F/u blood, urine, sputum cxs
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Switched to insulin drip yesterday.  Sugars over past 12 hours
   have all been 100 - 200; would continue drip given improved control.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: d/c allopurinol given constantly fluctuation renal function; can
   restart but give 100 mg every other day given poor GFR
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a complex medical history, including coronary artery bypass grafting, atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure. He is currently admitted to the ICU due to acute hypoxia, retroperitoneal bleed, acute/chronic renal failure, and abdominal distension.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia is likely multifactorial, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation, such as increasing PEEP or adjusting his ventilator settings.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fevers, leukocytosis, and positive Gram stain from sputum cultures suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory values is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels have been improving, but he may still be at risk for acute kidney injury due to his chronic kidney disease, hypotension, and potential nephrotoxic medications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's abdominal distension and coffee-ground material suctioned from his OG tube suggest that he may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring of his hemodynamic status and stool output is necessary to detect any signs of bleeding.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely contributing to his hypoxia, and he may require further interventions to control his heart rate and rhythm.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been fluctuating, and he may require further interventions to control his glucose levels, such as adjusting his insulin drip or adding other medications.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels may be imbalanced due to his chronic kidney disease, hypotension, and potential nephrotoxic medications. Close monitoring of his electrolyte levels is necessary to detect any imbalances.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Complications:
	* Hypoxia: The patient's SpO2 is 100% on 60% FiO2, which may not be sufficient to maintain adequate oxygenation. The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further due to underlying pulmonary edema, abdominal distension, and potential aspiration.
	* Pneumonia: The patient's sputum gram stain shows 4+ gram-negative rods and 2+ gram-positive cocci, which may indicate a bacterial infection.
2. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's systolic function is reduced (EF of 40%), and they have received multiple blood products, which may lead to fluid overload and cardiogenic shock.
	* Arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may worsen, and the pacemaker/defibrillator may not be functioning optimally.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's creatinine has been improving, but they may still be at risk for ATN due to hypotension, GI bleed, and cyst rupture.
	* Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's underlying chronic kidney disease may worsen due to the ongoing kidney injury and potential ATN.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding (UGIB): The patient has coffee-ground material suctioned from the OG tube, which may indicate ongoing bleeding.
	* Gastrointestinal Ischemia: The patient's reduced systolic function and potential hypotension may lead to gastrointestinal ischemia.
5. Neurological Complications:
	* Seizures: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and reduced systolic function may increase the risk of seizures.
	* Cerebral Edema: The patient's hypoxia and potential hypotension may lead to cerebral edema.
6. Infection Complications:
	* Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures may indicate sepsis.
	* Organ Dysfunction: The patient's underlying organ dysfunction (renal, cardiac, and respiratory) may worsen due to the ongoing infection.

These complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF. He was admitted with acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and r/o AMI. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show white blood cell count trending up, and respiratory sputum showing 4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci. His CXR shows continued resolution of patchy infiltrates bilaterally, with some residual abnormalities in the right upper lung.

The patient is receiving treatment for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone, and for UTI with vancomycin. He is also receiving treatment for retroperitoneal bleed with PRBC and FFP transfusions. His abdominal distension is likely secondary to ileus, and he is receiving treatment with PR bisacodyl, Reglan, and soap suds enema. His fevers and leukocytosis are likely secondary to CAP and UTI, and he is receiving treatment with vancomycin and azithromycin. He is also receiving treatment for atrial fibrillation with metoprolol.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still at risk for respiratory failure due to his chronic lung disease and pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is trending up, and he is receiving treatment for UTI and CAP. He is at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are steady, but he is at risk for acute kidney injury due to his chronic kidney disease and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and he is at risk for further bleeding due to his anticoagulation therapy and the use of NSAIDs.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and CHF, and he is at risk for developing cardiac complications such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections due to his immunosuppressed state and the use of antibiotics.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is at risk due to his gastrointestinal bleeding and ileus.
8. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient is at risk for developing electrolyte imbalances due to his chronic kidney disease and the use of diuretics.
9. Fluid overload: The patient is at risk for fluid overload due to his chronic kidney disease and the use of diuretics.
10. Pulmonary embolism: The patient is at risk for developing pulmonary embolism due to his immobility and the use of anticoagulation therapy.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has likely underlying pneumonia
   (white count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory
   sputum shows 4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs
   and chains.  Most likely to be community acquired since developed at
   time of admission and not coming from OSH; also not likely to be
   ventilator acquired since developed prior to being intubated.  Other
   reasons for hypoxia:  Also abdominal distension may reduce chest wall
   compliance, leading to hypoxemia.  Thirdly, he may have underlying
   pulmonary edema given his biventricular heart failure and that he
   received multiple RBCS + FFPs.  Finally, the patient is frequently
   overbreathing the ventilator and was previously in dyssynchrony with
   ventilator although seems to have improved.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 20, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP as tolerated to keep PO2 sats >
   90%.  Further improvement in CXR also suggests that respiratory status
   improvement likely secondary to continued resolution of PNA.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  White count
   still trending up, however respiratory status has improved and CXR
   looks resolved - continue coverage for CAP w/ ceftriaxone +
   azithromycin (day 4 of 8 day course).
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Due to CVVH was -0.8 L overnight, overall is
   total -0.8 L.  Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or
   just slightly negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively
   diurese.
   .
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinines are steady between 4.0
   and 5.0.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in
   setting of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may
   have led to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have
   further compromised renal function; may have reached new baseline.
   Continues to be oliguric (made 35 cc of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -In addition to PR bisacodyl would add soap suds enema
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   -Due to ileus and distension is having difficulties with tube feeds; if
   no resolution of ileus today, may have to consider D/C tube feeds and
   trying TPN.
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.  Started
   on vancomycin yesterday to cover this until we get sensitivities.
   -1/4 bottles is growing GPCs which could be contaminant;  although gram
   stain shows gram + cocci so could be enterococcus.  For now, continue
   coverage with vancomycin (day 2).  Follow-up blood cultures and
   sensitivities.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone for CAP (day 4 of 8 day course).
   Follow up sputum cultures.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF, who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia, acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, and r/o AMI. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His blood cultures show gram-positive cocci growing in pairs and clusters, and his urine culture shows >100,000 colonies of enterococcus. He has been diagnosed with CAP, and is being treated with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Renal Failure:** The patient has chronic kidney disease and has undergone CVVH. His creatinine levels are steady between 4.0 and 5.0, and he is oliguric. He may have reached a new baseline, and further deterioration of renal function is possible.
2. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient has hypoxia and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a history of pneumonia and may have underlying pulmonary edema. He may require further adjustment of his ventilator settings and may need to be weaned off the ventilator.
3. **Coagulopathy:** The patient has an INR of 1.2 and has received multiple blood products, including PRBCs and FFP. He is at risk for bleeding complications, particularly in the GI tract.
4. **Infection:** The patient has a urinary tract infection and is being treated with vancomycin. He also has a respiratory tract infection and is being treated with azithromycin and ceftriaxone. He is at risk for developing further infections, particularly in the ICU setting.
5. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient has abdominal distension and is at risk for developing ileus, which may require further management, including the use of laxatives and enemas.
6. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient has atrial fibrillation and is receiving metoprolol to control his heart rate. He is at risk for developing further cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
7. **Endocrine Complications:** The patient has diabetes and is receiving insulin drips. He is at risk for developing further endocrine complications, including hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
8. **Thrombotic Complications:** The patient is at risk for developing thrombotic complications, including DVT and pulmonary embolism, particularly given his immobility and the use of central lines and catheters.

Overall, the patient is at risk for developing multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation, now presenting with acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and pneumonia. He has a renal bleed possibly secondary to a renal cyst and is undergoing continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). His respiratory status is concerning for acute lung injury in the setting of significant renal ischemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Progressive Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is already impaired, and further deterioration may occur if CVVH is not effective or if there is ongoing renal ischemia.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning for acute lung injury, which may lead to further respiratory decline and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a blood culture positive for Gram-positive cocci (GPC) and is receiving antibiotics for pneumonia. Sepsis is a potential complication that may worsen the patient's condition.
4. Bleeding Complications: The patient has a renal bleed, and further bleeding complications may occur if anticoagulation is not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient has pneumonia and a blood culture positive for GPC, which may indicate a systemic infection that requires prompt treatment.
6. Fluid Overload: The patient is receiving CVVH and has a positive fluid balance, which may lead to fluid overload and further compromise his respiratory and cardiac function.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is on anticoagulation, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications such as cardiac arrest or stroke.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient is sedated and has a risk of neurological complications such as seizures or encephalopathy due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying Klebsiella
   pneumonia; further cx by fluid overload from receiving multiple BP (has
   CHF) and abdominal distension.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 15, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP to 10, with target of getting to 5
   as tolerated to keep PO2 sats > 90%.  Improvement in consolidation
   suggests that this improvement in respiratory status is due to
   resolution of underlying infection.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered with azithromycin and ceftriaxone which should cover both
   gram + and klebsiella and atypicals.  WBC plateau'd and now falling;
   continue  ceftriaxone + azithromycin (day 5 of 8 day course).
   -Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or just slightly
   negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively diurese.
   .
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine continuing to resolve,
   trended down to 3.6.  Cause of ARF likely secondary to ATN secondary to
   sustained hypoTN as well as intraparenchymal bleed.  Given chronic
   kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting of GI bleed, may
   have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led to ATN.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Continues to be
   oliguric (made 5cc /hr of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Aggressive bowel regimen:   PR bisacodyl, have tried soap suds enema.
   If still failing, can try milk + molasses (brown cow)
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis - Continues to be intermittently febrile but has
   largely resolved.
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Enterococcus is sensitive to ampicillin; can switch to this and
   continue to finish 10 day course.
   -1/4 bottles is growing GPCs is likely to be contaminant; Follow-up
   blood cultures and sensitivities.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone for CAP/klebsiella PNA (day 5 of
   8 day course). Follow up sputum cultures.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Went up on lantus this AM.  Sugars over past 12 hours have all
   been 100 - 200.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally
   dosed)
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes; if BM occurs today can start TF;
